$7,868 right now on Bitfinex: http://bitcoinity.org/markets. Today it briefly was at $8,119. It hasn't been below $5,000 since March. There isn't enough time before the forecast horizon for this latest bubble to collapse.

The price fell back down toward 7k after touching 8k but it found quite a bit of support as technical analysts would say as it bounced back amid a very high trading volume (the higher the volume, the more indicative of the market's view a certain price move is).  The close above 8k today suggests the bullish trend is unbroken for now at least.  One has to be somewhat skeptical of technical analysis like this. However, technical analysis is how many people trade, particularly in crypto (but also in various other markets such as oil and gold). It is useful to the extent that its indicators can serve as self-fulfilling prophecies.  Therefore, I am not putting a whole lot of weight on it. Given that the price is at 8k, historical base rates as expressed in my Monte Carlo Random Walk model suggest a low likelihood of a close below 7k by 31 May.

My last guess, based on Monte Carlo simulations of prior data, was made on 5 March, or over a month ago. Since then, BTC has rebounded strongly, making me toss the simulations out the window and go back to leaning on gut feel, looking at recent trends a little more closely. As of this moment, it sits at US$ 5258, so $5000 to $7000 has to be the most likely category. It's still not too far above $5000 so $3000 to $5000 is next. Recognizing that BTC is very volatile, my guesses are just that, and I'll have to come back to this and update as the deadline gets closer. This is a pretty significant change from my last forecast, which is justified by the fairly dramatic recent price fluctuations.
Adjusting after the big rally a few days ago.

For about 6 months now bitcoin has remained in the realm of $3K and $5K with the lower bound being $3,194 and the upper bound, as of today, being $5,102. Today marks a spike in recent bit coin changes, but after the spike in May of last year, the prices have decreased. As with most economies, there are ebbs and flows, and the price of bit coin has relatively spiked about 10-20% every other month over the past year. Therefore, seeing this spike, a larger one than in recent months, I can predict that by the end of May, the price will decrease back into a $4000-$5000 range.
Escape velocity achieved! Dialing back up to "crazy" levels.

I have done a crude monte carlo analysis using the daily changes since the peak on 16 December, 2017. I ran 21 trials, with minimum and maximum results of $1420 and $6265, and mean and standard deviation of $3311 and $1203. This gives me the following estimated probabilities, which I have rounded in my guess:
< $1000 - 2.7% (3%)
$1000 to $3000 - 37.1% (33%)
$3000 to $5000 - 52.2% (52%)
$5000 to $7000 - 7.9% (10%)
> $7000 - 0.1% (2%) It's very interesting (if only to me) that these results are VERY close to the consensus (crowd) forecast as of today (shown in brackets after my estimate).

BTC has been rangebound for a long period of time after the frenzy has died off, and one perhaps could speculate that, absent a shock or serious strengthening or weakening of the USD, this is the mean, or the natural exchange rate at least in the near term vs the USD as, unlike world economies, BTC has no country specific risk that might influence a modification of the exchange rate vs the USD.
Bitcoin is a safe haven currency and will explode in value for people living in countries going through financial crisis
Leading indicator shows strong BTC rally through end of May. The only question is probability of breaching $5000. Calculating an ending range of 4900-5500, or ~83% >= 5000.
The price broke through the 50 day moving average which typically presages bullishness.

The bitcoin is a ponzi scheme. As there is no inherent value except the value of people in the system attributed to the bitcoin, it requires a perpetuous inflow of new "believers" to increase the value. At the current state, I assume a stand still or slow slide downwards is the most likely scenario. The way the bitcoin is organized, inherently implies that one day someone will forget the password to access the last existing bitcoin wallet. If the decreasing power of miners didn't kill it earlier. The public permissionless blockchain is too demanding on resources, both on machines and humans, to be viable. In a constant struggle for convenience, bitcoin steadily heads the other way.
Expecting the breakout rally to begin within next 2 weeks.

It appears that there is a floor around $3,500.  I think the odds of it going above $5,000 are higher than the odds of going below $3,000 because of recent historical performance.  I would think buyers of Bitcoin would find some "value" around $3,000 reducing the odds of it going lower.  Long term I think it's headed below $1,000.

I've taken BTC price history from its peak in December 2017 to today, and projected an exponential best fit to come up with a best guess price on 31 May of $2403. It obviously won't be precisely that on that day, and the exponential fit is by no means the best way of estimating it, but if I had to make a bet with real money, I'd set the odds roughly along the lines of the probabilities I've chosen.

Who cares any more? Lots of other stuff happening in the world and if you can get a 20-25% uplift just by buying the FTSE index in the UK, on a non-Brexit relief rally, or if you want to short or back China depending on how you think trade talks are going, those look like hot picks compared to chasing a bunch of nerds around tiny markets in East Asia and California. The unforgivable sin - it's not fashionable any more.

Using @emil's Monte Carlos results as the baseline https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/816322 What could lead to an increase in the price of Bitcoin? The short answer is increased demand. How could demand increase? 
- a Bitcoin fund is approved by regulatory agencies (estimating 40% probability here, https://www.coindesk.com/bitwise-plans-new-bitcoin-etf-with-nyse-arca) 
- other asset classes loose appeal compared to Bitcoin (3% probability, I think trust by non-enthusiasts has taken a hit due to the volatility and severe depreciation, there needs to be a period of relative stability to offset that) 
- hard forks (almost certain to happen again, but maybe 15% probability in the timeframe of the question)  What could lead to a decrease in price? 
- hard forks (almost certain to happen again, but maybe 15% probability in the timeframe of the question) 
- introduction of regulations and restrictions by government, or speculation they might be introduced (20% probability in the timeframe of the question) 
- a competing cryptocurrency becomes more attractive (15% probability in the timeframe of the question) In conclusion I would say both sides are relatively balanced, especially since the timeframe of the question is relatively short. So forecasting the current trend to continue seems reasonable for now unless new information emerges.
Because I am falling for expert bias and also have invested in Bitcoin for years. I don't see other options

I estimated probabilities using a Monte Carlo model in the following steps: 1) Get data from the past 1 year (this is more representative of the current situation. In particular, using data from late 2017 would introduce a lot of volatility that is probably not representative. Data from https://www.coindesk.com/price/bitcoin 2) Estimate average % change in daily price and standard deviation. 3) Use these parameters to build a distribution (normal assumed) of future % daily changes.  4) Use this distribution to develop a pathway for the price over time (140 days since BTC trades every day) 5) Repeat step 4) 10,000 times 6) Tabulate frequencies of buckets Interestingly, it matters whether one uses the historical average or an average of 0 for the future distribution. Will BTC continue its 2018 trend? Or is it oversold and will it reverse? Assuming an average of 0 leads to 1%, 44%, 36%, 12% and 7% in the buckets respectively. Using the historical (0.3% daily drop) results in: 7, 67, 21, 4, 1. As a middle of the road assumption, I halved the average drop and used that.  Python Code: # BTC Monte Carlo
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from numpy import random # Forecasting formula
def forecast(days, start, avg, std):
    final_number = start
    for i in np.arange(days):
        change = np.random.normal(loc=avg,scale = std)
        final_number *= (1+change)
    return(final_number) # ~~~
# Process data
# ~~~ data = pd.read_csv('./BTC2018.csv')
data = data.set_index('date_UTC')
data = data['price_USD']
data = data.pct_change()[1:] # get daily % change
data.head() # ~~~
# Estimate parameters
# ~~~
avg = data.mean()
std = data.std()
avg = avg/2 import datetime
startDate = datetime.date(2019,1,11)
endDate = datetime.date(2019,5,31)
days = endDate - startDate
start = 3649 # Current price
days = days.days # Bitcoin trades every single day # ~~~
# Monte Carlo model
# ~~~ iterations = 10000
results = []
iter = 0
while iter < iterations:
    result = forecast(days, start, avg, std)
    results.append(result)
    iter += 1 # ~~~
# Results
# ~~~ from scipy.stats import percentileofscore
# Buckets:
percentileofscore(results,1000)
percentileofscore(results,3000)-percentileofscore(results,1000)
percentileofscore(results,5000)-percentileofscore(results,3000)
percentileofscore(results,7000)-percentileofscore(results,5000)
100-percentileofscore(results,7000)
Expecting a 25-35% retracement of ~$3200-19400 bear market range in that timeframe, giving $7250-8900 targets.
